Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other; Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowpit dug adjacent to an avalanche reported on February 17th. The pit location was a lower slope angle with less wind loading. There was a slight melt-freeze crust with small grained broken stellars with sharp edges above the crust. I think that right now to get an avalanche on this layer you need slope angle and some factor creating a denser slab (wind, sun, more snow).

Layer of greatest concern was new snow top 40cm that had some density changes that should settle out. Surface was cold graupel snow skiing.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Traditional site of first pit for the VHSG season. No. basal weakness detected with probing. No reaction to snowmachiners or skiing today. Variable snow surface between feathers to rhino hide. Some areas of breakable wind skin/slab up to 10cm thick, but was not propagating or cracking even on steep breakovers. No facets or surface hoar detected in the pit or on the surface during our tour.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Evidence of widespread avalanche activity prior to or during current storm. Avy debris observed near bottom of most avy path run-out zones up and down the Castle Crest zone. My best theory is that this debris and slide activity is the result of cornice failures during the recent warm sunny weather that preceded the current snow storm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: I encountered a variety of surface conditions throughout the day. An ice rink parking lot which turned rapidly to tropical temperatures and creamy corn snow. Then warm sastrugi followed by rime capped cold snow. Not a breath of wind till about 2k where then a thin ice rime layer developed. I skied from 2900 ft where winds became too much and snow conditions deteriorated. Flagging off all surrounding peaks in the area. Where I dug the full profile pit @1500 ft the TD was 320+. I dug another pit around 2400ft where the snowpack looked stronger and more rightside up.
Feb 02 interface buried 48cm down. Jan 04 interface buried 114cm down.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Roller balls observed on all aspects at this elevation. We do have enough of a temperature gradient at the interface between the Juneuary crust and the new snow to drive faceting. This could become a concern in the future. We will also watch for the formation of weak grain forms at the reactive interface at 175 cm.

Pit_Observation.activities: We snowmobiled slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Observed: CD Plotted: CD Site: Small convex knoll within undulating meadows above lake at TL. Below small stand of conifer. Objective: Analyze the post-snowfall structure of the upper snowpack. Investigate the presence/sensitivity of buried SH.

Went to check stability on a west aspect at a similar elevation, and not far from a recent avalanche. We picked up nearly 3' of snow over the past 10 days at 3.7" SWE that produced two rounds of significant natural activity down to basal faceted layers, primarily on N-NE-E aspects. A few avalanches were observed on west aspects.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: My layer of greatest concern is still the persistent weak layer located between 50 cm and 0 cm. This layer was greater than 1 meter below the top of the snowpack, so my CT and ECT did not test this layer. I did get fractures in both tests at the interface between my pen hard and 1F+ layer at 91 cm, as well as at 142 cm at a density change in the storm snow. The fracture at 91 cm did propagate in the ECT, but it did not easily slide off the block in my CT. When I did pull on my column in both the ECT and CT, the column failed at the persistent weak layer interface at 50 cm but did not fail at 91 cm or 142 cm. I'm not sure what this means, but it was interesting.

User.name: Cory Beattie

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This snowpit was dug in a similar spot to a pit on 2/1/2024 and an avalanche from 1/30/2024. There is now an additional 80cm of snow over the weak layer for a total slab depth of of 120cm in this location. The weak layer is as weak as it was with more weight over the top. Thicker snowpack does not equal stronger snowpack.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: There was about 0-5 cm difference in the depth of new snow on the end of January melt layer. The ECT was unreliable due to poor column isolation. I had trouble isolating the column by myself and it got progressively thinner towards the bottom.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Snowmobile tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in crown of a deep persistent slab avalanche that was triggered by a snowmobile on Feb 5 at 3 pm. Avalanche failure layer buried on Dec 19. ECT performed 30 feet down the flank from pit in crown. At ECT in the flank, the weak layer ranged from 80 to 105 cm below the snow surface.
